text: so let's go back to some positive news
the Prime Minister has been moved from
the intensive care units where he has
spent the last three nights at st.
Thomas's Hospital we can cross over to
our correspondent there Keith Doyle who
joins us live now Keith with this news
breaking in the past hour or so what do
we know Keith yes well we have been
given a statement from Downing Street to
say that the Prime Minister has now left
the intensive care unit the statement
from Downing Street says that the Prime
Minister has been moved back this
evening from intensive care back to the
ward where he will where he will receive
close monitoring during the early phase
of his recovery and the statement went
on to say that he is in extremely good
spirits of course the key word in there
is the early phase of his recovery so
clearly he has passed that pointer of
danger at that point that we're all
worried about that he was in intensive
care for he's now out of intensive care
and his recovery has begun he was
brought to the hospital here in central
London last Sunday and then he was
brought into intensive care on Monday
night so we spent three nights in
intensive care no we did here throughout
through various government briefings
over the last few days
certainly this morning or this afternoon
Dominic Rab who's the Foreign Secretary
of course deputizing for the prime
minister he said that he was in in good
spirits and that he was taking steps
towards his recovery and of course this
news coming tonight just in the last
hour that the Prime Minister Boris
Johnson has now been moved out of
intensive care and is back in the ward
where in the words of a spokesperson
said that he will receive close
monitoring during the early phase of his
recovery and we've had some reaction to
that the the president Trump has tweeted
that great news Boris Johnson is out of
intensive care and he ends his texts by
saying or ends his tweet by saying get
well Boris and it's really good it's
positive to hear that the Prime Minister
is in extremely good spirits just a few
moments ago we of course had the clap
for
workers for the NHS these are pictures
that were taking place about 8 or so
minutes ago the Prime Minister himself
Keith took part in this last week when
this happened this is now becoming a bit
of a ritual every Thursday evening at 8
o'clock in UK time so this time he was
in the hands of the NHS the government's
always very keen to stress that he is
receiving excellent care and we heard
that message on Monday when he was first
admitted into intensive care and now we
know that he has been moved from
intensive care but he does remain on the
ward at st. Thomas's yes well of course
it was last Thursday night when the
whole of the UK came out to clap for the
NHS for the National Health Service that
we saw those pictures of Boris Johnson
on the steps in Downing Street standing
alone clapping for the NHS and indeed I
mean to most observers he did not look
well in those pictures he really felt
that they certainly looked like he was
not making the type of recovery that
everyone would have hoped for and of
course it was just a few days later that
he was taken here to st. Thomas's
Hospital so yes that good news tonight
within the last hour that statement
coming from Downing Street to say that
the Prime Minister has been moved back
this evening from intensive care back
into the ward where he will receive
close monitoring during the early phase
of his recovery so clearly the recovery
of the prime minister from coronavirus
has begun good news thank you so much
Keith Keith door there outside st.
Thomas's Hospital in central London
where the Prime Minister has been moved
from intensive care
